intro.p: Provides usefull common methods to generate HTML tags.

note.p: This helper provides the means to generate commonly used HTML tags. All of it's methods return System.String that holds resulting HTML.

section.title: HtmlHelper()
section.p: Initializes a new instance of the Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper class.

section.title: SetController(Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Controller controller)
section.p: Sets the controller.

section.title: FieldSet(System.String legend) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a fieldset
tag with a legend. <fieldset><legend>legendArg</legend>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.FieldSet(System.String) together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndFieldSet
: $HtmlHelper.FieldSet( "legendArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndFieldSet()

note.p:
Calling FieldSet( "legendArg" )
results in: <fieldset><legend>legendArg</legend>

tr.td: Legend to use within the fieldset.

section.title: EndFieldSet() : System.String
section.p:
Creates a closing fieldset
tag. </fieldset>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.FieldSet(System.String) together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndFieldSet
: $HtmlHelper.FieldSet( "legendArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndFieldSet()

note.p:
This method should be invoked after Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.FieldSet(System.String) to close the fieldset. Calling EndFieldSet()
results in: </fieldset>

section.title: Form(System.String action) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a form tag with "post" method and specified action
. <form method="post" action="actionArg">
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.Form(System.String) together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndForm
: $HtmlHelper.Form( "actionArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndForm()

note.p:
Calling Form( "actionArg" )
results in: <form method="post" action="actionArg">

section.title: Form(System.String action, System.String id, System.String method) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a form tag with specified method, action and id
. <form method="methodArg" action="actionArg" id="idArg">
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Form together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndForm
: $HtmlHelper.Form( "actionArg", "idArg", "methodArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndForm()

note.p:
Calling Form( "actionArg", "idArg", "methodArg" )
results in: <form method="methodArg" action="actionArg" id="idArg">

section.title: Form(System.String action, System.String id, System.String method, System.String onSubmit) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a form tag with specified method, action, id and onSubmit
event handler. <form method="methodArg" action="actionArg" id="idArg" onsubmit="onSubmitArg">
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Form together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndForm
: $HtmlHelper.Form( "actionArg", "idArg", "methodArg", "submitHandler()" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndForm()

note.p:
Calling Form( "actionArg", "idArg", "methodArg", "onSubmitArg" )
results in: <form method="methodArg" action="actionArg" id="idArg" onsubmit="onSubmitArg">

tr.td: JavaScript inline code to be invoked upon form submission.

section.title: Form(System.String action, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a form tag the specified action
. <form action="actionArg">

tr.td: Html Attributes for the form tag

section.title: EndForm() : System.String
section.p:
Creates a closing form
tag. </form>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.Form(System.String) together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndForm
: $HtmlHelper.Form( "actionArg", "idArg", "methodArg", "submitHandler()" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndForm()

note.p:
Calling EndForm()
results in: </form>

section.title: Link(System.String target, System.String linkText) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the target linkText
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Link
: $HtmlHelper.Link( "mypage.html", "This is a link to my page" )

note.p: Calling Link( "something.html", "to something" ) results in: something

section.title: Link(System.String target, System.String linkText, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the target linkText
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Link
: $HtmlHelper.Link( "mypage.html", "This is a link to my page", $DictHelper.CreateDict("class=mylinkclass") )

note.p: Calling Link( "something.html", "to something", $DictHelper.CreateDict("class=mylinkclass") ) results in: something

tr.td: Additional attributes for the a tag.

section.title: LinkTo(System.String name, System.String action) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the action on the current controller. nameArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use LinkTo
: $HtmlHelper.LinkTo( "linkName", "requiredAction" )

note.p: Calling LinkTo( "nameArg", "actionArg" ) results in: nameArg

section.title: LinkTo(System.String name, System.String controller, System.String action) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the action on the specified controller . nameArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use LinkTo
: $HtmlHelper.LinkTo( "linkName", "someController", "requiredAction" )

note.p: Calling LinkTo( "nameArg", "controllerArg", "actionArg" ) results in: nameArg

section.title: LinkTo(System.String name, System.String controller, System.String action, System.Object id) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the action on the specified controller passing provided id . nameArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use LinkTo
: $HtmlHelper.LinkTo( "linkName", "someController", "requiredAction", objectToRefByID )

note.p: Calling LinkTo( "nameArg", "controllerArg", "actionArg", object ) results in: nameArg System.String.Format(System.String,System.Object) is used to convert id to the actual System.String.

tr.td: Object to use for the action ID argument.

section.title: LinkToAttributed(System.String name, System.String controller, System.String action, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the action on the specified controller nameArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use LinkToAttributed
: $HtmlHelper.LinkToAttributed( "linkName", "someController", "requiredAction", $DictHelper.CreateDict("class=something") )

note.p: Calling LinkToAttributed( "nameArg", "controllerArg", "actionArg", IDictionary ) results in: nameArg

tr.td: Additional attributes for the a tag.

section.title: LinkToAttributed(System.String name, System.String controller, System.String action, System.Object id, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p: Creates an anchor (link) to the action on the specified controller nameArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use LinkToAttributed
: $HtmlHelper.LinkToAttributed( "linkName", "someController", "requiredAction", $DictHelper.CreateDict("class=something") )

note.p: Calling LinkToAttributed( "nameArg", "controllerArg", "actionArg", IDictionary ) results in: nameArg

tr.td: Additional attributes for the a tag.

section.title: MapToVirtual(System.String target) : System.String
section.p:
Maps target
to website virtual path. /website/targetArg
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.MapToVirtual(System.String)
: $HtmlHelper.MapToVirtual( "targetFolder/targetFile.html" )

note.p:
Calling MapToVirtual( "targetArg" )
results in: /website/targetArg

section.title: LabelFor(System.String forId, System.String label) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a label for the element indicated with forId
. <label for="forIdArg">labelArg</label>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.LabelFor(System.String,System.String)
: $HtmlHelper.LabelFor( "forIdArg", "labelArg" )

note.p:
Calling LabelFor( "forIdArg", "labelArg" )
results in: <label for="forIdArg">labelArg</label>

tr.td: ID of the element for which to create the lable.

section.title: LabelFor(System.String forId, System.String label, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p:
Creates a label for the element indicated with forId
. <label key1="value1" key2="value2" for="forIdArg">labelArg</label>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.LabelFor(System.String,System.String)
: $HtmlHelper.LabelFor( "forIdArg", "labelArg", IDictionary )

note.p:
Calling LabelFor( "forIdArg", "labelArg", IDictionary )
results in: <label key5="value5" key4="value4" key1="value1" key3="value3" key2="value2" for="forIdArg">labelArg</label>

tr.td: ID of the element for which to create the label.
Additional attributes to add to the label.

section.title: DateTime(System.String name, System.DateTime value) : System.String
section.p:
Creates three select
tags to input day, month and year. <select name="nameArgday" id="nameArgday" > ... </select> <select name="nameArgmonth" id="nameArgmonth" > ... </select> <select name="nameArgyear" id="nameArgyear" > ... </select>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use DateTime
: $HtmlHelper.DateTime( "nameArg", new DateTime( 2005, 07, 15 ) )

note.p:
Calling DateTime( "nameArg", new DateTime( 2005, 07, 15 ) )
results in: <select name="nameArgday" id="nameArgday" > <option>1</option> <option>2</option> ... <option>14</option> <option selected>15</option> <option>16</option> ... <option>30</option> <option>31</option> </select> <select name="nameArgmonth" id="nameArgmonth" > <option>1</option> <option>2</option> ... <option>6</option> <option selected>7</option> <option>8</option> ... <option>11</option> <option>12</option> </select> <select name="nameArgyear" id="nameArgyear" > <option>1930</option> <option>1931</option> ... <option>2004</option> <option selected>2005</option> <option>2006</option> ... <option>2029</option> </select> As above example shows the year range is hardcoded between 1930 and 2029.
name is used to generate name and id for each select tag. Supplied System.String is concatenated with "day", "month", or "year" to create System.String for the tag attributes.

tr.td: Name to use with name and id arguments of the select tag.
System.DateTime to use for default selected date.

section.title: DateTime(System.String name, System.DateTime value, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p:
Creates three select
tags to input day, month and year. <select name="nameArgday" id="nameArgday" key1="value1" key3="value3" key2="value2" > ... </select> <select name="nameArgmonth" id="nameArgmonth" key1="value1" key3="value3" key2="value2" > ... </select> <select name="nameArgyear" id="nameArgyear" key1="value1" key3="value3" key2="value2" > ... </select>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use DateTime
: $HtmlHelper.DateTime( "nameArg", new DateTime( 2005, 07, 15 ), IDictionary )

note.p:
Calling DateTime( "nameArg", new DateTime( 2005, 07, 15 ), IDictionary )
results in: <select name="nameArgday" id="nameArgday" key1="value1" key2="value2" > <option>1</option> <option>2</option> ... <option>14</option> <option selected>15</option> <option>16</option> ... <option>30</option> <option>31</option> </select> <select name="nameArgmonth" id="nameArgmonth" key1="value1" key2="value2" > <option>1</option> <option>2</option> ... <option>6</option> <option selected>7</option> <option>8</option> ... <option>11</option> <option>12</option> </select> <select name="nameArgyear" id="nameArgyear" key1="value1" key2="value2" > <option>1930</option> <option>1931</option> ... <option>2004</option> <option selected>2005</option> <option>2006</option> ... <option>2029</option> </select> As above example shows the year range is hardcoded between 1930 and 2029.
name is used to generate name and id for each select tag. Supplied System.String is concatenated with "day", "month", or "year" to create System.String for the tag attributes.
attributes is used to generate additional attributes for each of the select tags. System.Collections.IDictionary.Keys are used to name attributes. System.Collections.IDictionary.Values are used to assign those attributes values.

tr.td: Name to use with name and id arguments of the select tag.
System.DateTime to use for default selected date.

section.title: TextArea(System.String name, System.Int32 cols, System.Int32 rows, System.String value) : System.String
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.TextArea(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
: $HtmlHelper.TextArea( "nameArg", 10, 20, "Text inside text area." )

note.p:
Calling TextArea( "nameArg", 10, 10, "valueArg" )
results in: <textarea id="nameArg" name="nameArg" cols="10" rows="10">valueArg</textarea>

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.
Text to place inside of the text area.

section.title: InputButton(System.String value) : System.String

p.p: Creates an input element of the button type.

section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputButton
: $HtmlHelper.InputButton( "valueArg" )

note.p:
Calling InputButton( "valueArg" )
results in: <input type="button" name="valueArg" value="valueArg" />

p.p: Creates an input element of the button type.

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.

section.title: InputButton(System.String name, System.String value, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String

p.p: Creates an input element of the button type.

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.
Additional attributes for the input tag.

section.title: InputText(System.String name, System.String value) : System.String

p.p: Creates an input element of the text type.

section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputText
: $HtmlHelper.InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg" )

note.p:
Calling InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg" )
results in: <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" />

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.

section.title: InputText(System.String name, System.String value, System.Int32 size, System.Int32 maxlength) : System.String
section.p:
Creates an input element of the text type of specified size and maxlength
. <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" size="10" maxlength="10" />
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputText
: $HtmlHelper.InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", 10, 10 )

note.p:
Calling InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", 10, 10 )
results in: <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" size="10" maxlength="10" />

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.

section.title: InputText(System.String name, System.String value, System.Int32 size, System.Int32 maxlength, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p:
Creates an input element of the text type with specified size, maxlength and attributes
. <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" size="10" maxlength="10" />
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputText
: $HtmlHelper.InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", 10, 10, IDictionary )

note.p:
Calling InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", 10, 10, IDictionary )
results in: <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" size="10" maxlength="10" key1="value1" key2="value2" />
attributes is used to generate additional attributes for the label tag. System.Collections.IDictionary.Keys are used to name attributes. System.Collections.IDictionary.Values are used to assign those attributes values.

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.
Additional attributes for the input tag.

section.title: InputText(System.String name, System.String value, System.String id) : System.String
section.p:
Creates an input element of the text type with custom name and id
. <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="idArg" value="valueArg" />
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputText
: $HtmlHelper.InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", "idArg" )

note.p:
Calling InputText( "nameArg", "valueArg", "idArg" )
results in: <input type="text" name="nameArg" id="idArg" value="valueArg" />

section.title: InputText(System.String name, System.String value, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p: Missing summary

section.p: Creates an input element of password type

section.p: Creates an input element of password type

section.p: Creates an input element of password type

section.title: InputHidden(System.String name, System.String value) : System.String
section.p: Creates an input hidden element
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputHidden
: $HtmlHelper.InputHidden( "nameArg", "valueArg" )

note.p:
Calling InputHidden( "nameArg", "valueArg" )
results in: <input type="hidden" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="valueArg" />

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.

section.title: InputHidden(System.String name, System.Object value) : System.String

p.p: Creates a hidden type input element.

section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use InputHidden
: $HtmlHelper.InputHidden( "nameArg", object )

note.p:
Calling InputHidden( "nameArg", object )
results in: <input type="hidden" name="nameArg" id="nameArg" value="object" />
System.String for value attribute is retrieved from value via System.Object.ToString.
If value is nullSystem.String.Empty is used as the valueSystem.String.

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.
System.Object to supply System.String for value attribute.

section.title: SubmitButton(System.String value) : System.String
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use SubmitButton
: $HtmlHelper.SubmitButton( "valueArg" )

note.p:
Calling SubmitButton( "valueArg" )
results in: <input type="submit" value="valueArg" />

section.title: SubmitButton(System.String value, System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.section:

This example shows how to use SubmitButton
: $HtmlHelper.SubmitButton( "valueArg", IDictionary )

note.p:
Calling SubmitButton( "valueArg", IDictionary )
results in: <input type="submit" value="valueArg" key1="value1" key2="value2" />
attributes is used to generate additional attributes for the label tag. System.Collections.IDictionary.Keys are used to name attributes. System.Collections.IDictionary.Values are used to assign those attributes values.

tr.td: Additional attributes for the input tag.

section.p:
Creates opening select
tag. <select name="nameArg" id="nameArg">

: $HtmlHelper.Select( "nameArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndSelect()

Calling Select( "nameArg" )
results in: <select name="nameArg" id="nameArg">

Creates opening select
tag. <select name="nameArg" id="nameArg" key1="value1" key2="value2" >

This example shows how to use Select together with Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.EndSelect

Calling Select( "nameArg", IDictionary )
results in: <select name="nameArg" id="nameArg" key1="value1" key2="value2" >
attributes is used to generate additional attributes for the label tag. System.Collections.IDictionary.Keys are used to name attributes. System.Collections.IDictionary.Values are used to assign those attributes values.

tr.td: Value for name and id attributes.
Additional attributes for the select tag.

section.p: Creates a closing select tag.

: $HtmlHelper.Select( "nameArg" ) ... $HtmlHelper.EndSelect()

Calling EndSelect()
results in: </select>

section.title: EndOptionGroup() : System.String
section.p: Missing summary

section.title: CreateOption(System.String text, System.Object value) : System.String
section.p: TODO: Document this!

section.title: CreateOption(System.String text, System.Object value, System.Collections.IDictionary htmlAttributes) : System.String
section.p: TODO: Document this!

note.p: Valid html attributes include: selected and disabled

section.title: CreateOptionsFromPrimitiveArray(System.Array elems, System.String selected) : System.String
section.p:
Creates option elements from System.Array. Marks the option that matches the selected
argument (if provided). <option>0</option> <option>1</option> ... <option>5</option> <option selected>selectedArg</option> <option>object</option>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use CreateOptionsFromPrimitiveArray
: $HtmlHelper.CreateOptionsFromPrimitiveArray( Array, "selectedArg" )

note.p:
Calling CreateOptionsFromPrimitiveArray( Array, "selectedArg" )
results in: <option>0</option> <option>1</option> <option>2</option> <option>3</option> <option>4</option> <option>5</option> <option selected>selectedArg</option> <option>object</option>
Elements in the array are converted to System.String using System.Text.StringBuilder.AppendFormat(System.String,System.Object).

tr.td: Array of values for each option tag.
Name of the option tag to mark selected.

section.title: CreateOptionsFromArray(System.Array elems, System.String textProperty, System.String valueProperty) : System.String
section.p:
Creates options elements from an System.Array
. <option value="valueProp">textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use CreateOptions
: $HtmlHelper.CreateOptionsFromArray( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg" )

note.p:
Calling CreateOptionsFromArray( Array, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with specific type objects results in: <option value="valueProp">textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
Calling CreateOptionsFromArray( Array, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with random type objects results in: <option>0</option> <option>1</option> <option>2</option> <option>3</option> <option>4</option> <option>5</option> <option>object</option> <option>MR.Logic.Controllers.HtmlHelperController+SampleClass</option> Notice that the last option was generated from an object of the type with the properties specified by textProperty and , but the method is already in the mode of working with random type objects. Explanation bellow describes two different modes of working with the method.
There are two possible usages of the method depending on the types of System.Objects which can be present in elems:
Random type objectsArray is full of random type objects. Properties specified by textProperty and aren't used. Instead value argument is ommited and System.Object.ToString is invoked on each item in elems to retrieve text for an option tag.
Single type objectsArray is objects of one time. In this case textProperty and valueProperty can specify the names of the properties of that type to use for option tags generation. You cannot mix random type objects and specific type objects. CreateOptionsFromArray is looking at the first item in the elems collection to get System.Reflection.MethodInfo to access specified properties. If usage is mixed either an unexpected exception will be thrown or options will have unexpected strings.
CreateOptionsFromArray relies on Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.CreateOptions(System.Collections.ICollection,System.String,System.String) to generate all option tags.

tr.td: Collection of objects each of which describes an option tag.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's text.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's value attribute value.

section.title: CreateOptionsFromArray(System.Array elems, System.String textProperty, System.String valueProperty, System.Object selectedValue) : System.String
section.p:
Creates options elements from an System.Array
. <option value="valueProp" selected>textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use CreateOptions
: $HtmlHelper.CreateOptionsFromArray( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )

note.p:
Calling CreateOptionsFromArray( Array, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with specific type objects results in: <option value="valueProp" selected>textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
Calling CreateOptionsFromArray( Array, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with random type objects results in: <option>0</option> <option>1</option> <option>2</option> <option>3</option> <option>4</option> <option>5</option> <option selected>object</option> <option>MR.Logic.Controllers.HtmlHelperController+SampleClass</option> Notice that the last option was generated from an object of the type with the properties specified by textProperty and , but the method is already in the mode of working with random type objects. Explanation bellow describes two different modes of working with the method.
There are two possible usages of the method depending on the types of System.Objects which can be present in elems:
Random type objectsArray is full of random type objects. Properties specified by textProperty and aren't used. Instead value argument is ommited and System.Object.ToString is invoked on each item in elems to retrieve text for an option tag.
Single type objectsArray is objects of one time. In this case textProperty and valueProperty can specify the names of the properties of that type to use for option tags generation. You cannot mix random type objects and specific type objects. CreateOptionsFromArray is looking at the first item in the elems collection to get System.Reflection.MethodInfo to access specified properties. If usage is mixed either an unexpected exception will be thrown or options will have unexpected strings.
CreateOptionsFromArray relies on Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.HtmlHelper.CreateOptions(System.Collections.ICollection,System.String,System.String) to generate all option tags.

tr.td: Collection of objects each of which describes an option tag.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's text.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's value attribute value.
System.Object indicating which option tag is to be marked with selected attribute.

section.title: CreateOptions(System.Collections.ICollection elems, System.String textProperty, System.String valueProperty) : System.String
section.p:
Creates options elements from an System.Collections.ICollection
. <option value="valueProp">textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use CreateOptions
: $HtmlHelper.CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg" )

note.p:
Calling CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with specific type objects results in: <option value="valueProp">textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
Calling CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with random type objects results in: <option>0</option> <option>1</option> <option>2</option> <option>3</option> <option>4</option> <option>5</option> <option>object</option> <option>MR.Logic.Controllers.HtmlHelperController+SampleClass</option> Notice that the last option was generated from an object of the type with the properties specified by textProperty and , but the method is already in the mode of working with random type objects. Explanation bellow describes two different modes of working with the method.
There are two possible usages of the method depending on the types of System.Objects which can be present in elems:
Random type objectsArray is full of random type objects. Properties specified by textProperty and aren't used. Instead value argument is ommited and System.Object.ToString is invoked on each item in elems to retrieve text for an option tag.
Single type objectsArray is objects of one time. In this case textProperty and valueProperty can specify the names of the properties of that type to use for option tags generation. You cannot mix random type objects and specific type objects. CreateOptions is looking at the first item in the elems collection to get System.Reflection.MethodInfo to access specified properties. If usage is mixed either an unexpected exception will be thrown or options will have unexpected strings.

tr.td: Collection of objects each of which describes an option tag.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's text.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's value attribute value.

section.title: CreateOptions(System.Collections.ICollection elems, System.String textProperty, System.String valueProperty, System.Object selectedValue) : System.String
section.p:
Creates options elements from an System.Collections.ICollection
. <option value="valueProp" selected>textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use CreateOptions
: $HtmlHelper.CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )

note.p:
Calling CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with specific type objects results in: <option value="valueProp" selected>textProp</option> <option value="0">textProp2</option> <option value="5">textProp3</option>
Calling CreateOptions( ICollection, "textPropertyArg", "valuePropertyArg", object )
with random type objects results in: <option>0</option> <option>1</option> <option>2</option> <option>3</option> <option>4</option> <option>5</option> <option selected>object</option> <option>MR.Logic.Controllers.HtmlHelperController+SampleClass</option> Notice that the last option was generated from an object of the type with the properties specified by textProperty and , but the method is already in the mode of working with random type objects. Explanation bellow describes two different modes of working with the method.
There are two possible usages of the method depending on the types of System.Objects which can be present in elems:
Random type objectsArray is full of random type objects. Properties specified by textProperty and aren't used. Instead value argument is ommited and System.Object.ToString is invoked on each item in elems to retrieve text for an option tag.
Single type objectsArray is objects of one time. In this case textProperty and valueProperty can specify the names of the properties of that type to use for option tags generation. You cannot mix random type objects and specific type objects. CreateOptions is looking at the first item in the elems collection to get System.Reflection.MethodInfo to access specified properties. If usage is mixed either an unexpected exception will be thrown or options will have unexpected strings.

tr.td: Collection of objects each of which describes an option tag.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's text.
Name of the elems objects property with the value for each option tag's value attribute value.
System.Object indicating which option tag is to be marked with selected attribute.

section.title: BuildUnorderedList(System.Collections.ICollection elements) : System.String
section.p:
Builds an unordered ul list from supplied System.Collections.ICollection .
  • 0
    • ...
  • object
section.section:
Example
This example shows how to use BuildUnorderedList
: $HtmlHelper.BuildUnorderedList( ICollection )

note.p:
Calling BuildUnorderedList( ICollection ) results in:
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
  • 4
  • 5
  • object
Items in elements are converted to string through System.Object.ToString.

tr.td: Collection with items to use for the list generation.

section.title: BuildUnorderedList(System.Collections.ICollection elements, System.String styleClass, System.String itemClass) : System.String

Builds an unordered ul list from supplied System.Collections.ICollection with ul and li tags CSS class set to supplied attributes.
  1. 0
    2. ...
  2. object

note.p:
Calling BuildUnorderedList( ICollection, "styleClassArg", "itemClassArg" ) results in:
  1. 0
  2. 1
  3. 2
  4. 3
  5. 4
  6. 5
  7. object
Items in elements are converted to string through System.Object.ToString.

tr.td: Collection with items to use for the list generation.
CSS class name of the list ul tag.
CSS class name of the list item li tag.

section.title: MergeOptions(System.Collections.IDictionary userOptions, System.Collections.IDictionary defaultOptions)
section.p: Merges userOptions with defaultOptions placing results in userOptions.

section.title: GetAttributes(System.Collections.IDictionary attributes) : System.String
section.p:
Generates HTML element attributes string from attributes
. key1="value1" key2

section.title: HtmlEncode(System.String content) : System.String
section.p: HTML encodes a string and returns the encoded string.

section.title: UrlEncode(System.String content) : System.String
section.p: URL encodes a string and returns the encoded string.

section.title: UrlPathEncode(System.String content) : System.String
section.p: URL encodes the path portion of a URL string and returns the encoded string.

section.title: JavaScriptEscape(System.String content) : System.String
section.p: Escapes JavaScript with Url encoding and returns the encoded string.
